text:
Basically because programs can have side effects in a way music/film can't. If you have a program that makes a random Tweet, or writes a file, then you have to decide what skipping back and forth over this line does - i.e. does it repeatedly execute the side effect?

In a normal debugger like Visual Studio, which doesn't record and had stepping back added on later, it repeats the side effect. I think users feel much safer playing with a recording which isn't actually running while you are debugging.

text:
That makes a lot of sense! I do feel that seeing how a code behaves for different inputs can be helpful, but if there are side effects, it will definitely be more confusing, and likely have undesirable outcomes. I'll keep this in mind if I decide to do an exploration focused on "execution control".

Thanks again for sharing!

text:
>  Do you agree with me that we are doing productive/useful "work" in algebra with just rearrangement?
Yes definitely useful. Isn't this the entire premise of formal logic and logical entailment? We can do mechanical transforms on well formed sentences (or sets of sentences) and produce new sentences that "hold", or determine that some sentences don't hold. This is unrelated to what many words in the sentence actually _mean_ to us.

In terms of if this is the 'linguistic part' of the brain or not - I don't know. Usually linguistics includes the study of semantics (~meaning) and not just structural patterns.

> And I don't think you do know there is an agent
True, the model could be wrong. The main thing is we carry around a large set of models and facts in our heads. Given some new fact, we associate it with this stuff we already have in our heads. In 'kid eats breakfast', there is an involuntary and fast association with 'kid' , 'breakfast' and 'eat', all of which have vast related facts and connotations in my mind. Maybe this makes it easier to manipulate? With something like `a*(b+c)` there is nothing else in our mind to connect with, except the learned rules of structural manipulation, which I have to actively search. TBH in this specific case, I remember the pattern and am easily able to match and rearrange it to `a*b + a*c` . However in most cases we don't have a quick pattern recognition - or even a name for the pattern or names for some symbols. Maybe this makes it harder to manipulate.
